Award.AwardTitle: Destination Problem-Based Learning: A Large Scale Materials Development Project

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: In problem-based learning models, such as scenario-based learning (SBL), learning activities are situated in contexts that resemble those students would encounter in the workplace. Yet integrating scenario-based learning into the community college environment requires change and an understanding of the ways that this pedagogical approach can be adapted to meet the needs of the faculty practitioner. Action research is used to engage faculty, under the guidance of professional researchers, in examining the challenges of implementing SBL instruction in technician education. An online community of practice is developed by establishing a library of SBL resources and by linking to ATE centers and projects, initially in biology and bio-informatics. Three prototype online wizards are developed and tested to support community college instructors in editing existing SBL activities, in creating new SBL activities and in creating principled assessments items using the ideas of evidence-centered design. An advisory board of industry representatives and educational researchers in the fields of teaming, problem based learning and collaborative learning guide the development and validation of the scenarios. The evaluation determines metrics to measure the extent to which the SBLs prove useful to faculty and students in technical education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Destination: Problem-Based Learning (DPBL) project at Truckee Meadows Community College in Reno, Nevada (2011-2015) advocated for the scaling up of problem-based learning (PBL) nationally though (a) deepening our understanding of PBL in practice through faculty inquiry and research; (b) sustaining our work through communities of practice around PBL that support faculty-led efforts to expand the adoption of PBL in workforce education; and (c) spreading knowledge of how to implement, revise, assess, or create PBL curriculum materials and how to facilitate PBL workshops and build PBL community.

The broader impact of the project centers around the dissemination of quality PBL nationally, including the development of models, methods, and tools designed to support PBL faculty and students. The intellectual merit of the project includes building community and developing faculty professional development to sustain change in educational practices and structures as well as examining the impact of PBL on faculty and student self-efficacy and personal resilience.

PBL is a philosophy of education that centers the experience on the student as a whole being who co-builds the learning with fellow students, the instructor, and the community. PBL challenges students to solve real-world problems, create the deliverables, and present reports that match what they will face in their professional careers.

How do we know they are real world problems? Because we ask industry to review them, be involved in their development, be present at their presentations, and be part of the educational experience for the students. The key is that the students are presented with each task before they are presented with lectures. They then, with just-in-time guidance from faculty, collectively build the knowledge they need to deliver the solutions.

Over time we came to realize the value added by PBL went beyond the introduction of professional skills (e.g. communication, teamwork, problem-solving) into the education of technicians. PBL also challenges students to exercise courage, creativity, and leadership skills that will serve them well in their careers and life.

Our best PBL instructors challenge and support their students to do what might seem to be the impossible. The productive persistence needed to solve a rigorous challenge leads to deeper learning and increased belief by the students in their ability to master whatever comes there way.Instructors report that the more challenged their students were, the more engaged they became.

So how do you create PBL in in the classroom? It is not just an issue of developing new curriculum. We worked with faculty, administrators, students, and industry professionals from 34+ states and several countries to develop, test, revise, adopt, adapt, and research methods and tools for implementing PBL in community college, university, and high school classrooms. Our faculty struggled with persisting through the challenge of changing the culture of their classroom. They learned from experts and very much benefited from ongoing support from peers.

After experimenting with several models of faculty development, ranging from webinars to conference workshops to week-long resident workshops, we found that an Extended Care model (see graphic) and Faculty Inquiry cohorts provided sustained support from experts and peers that faculty needed to successfully change their professional practice from traditional lectures to PBL. Our Faculty Inquiry cohorts brought together university, community college, and high school biotech faculty to support each other in an online community to adapt and adopt our BioInformatice Intern Project scenario and tasks. See our website for articles and graphics about their work.
